Abstract: Recent advances in molecular biology have significantly transformed our understanding of breathing control, revealing intricate mechanisms underlying respiratory function. The preBÃ¶tC nucleus, a critical component of the respiratory control system, has been found to interact with various molecular tools, including lung sensory neurons and the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS). The Hering-Breuer inflation reflex, a fundamental mechanism regulating lung inflation, has been shown to be modulated by serotonin, a neurotransmitter involved in regulating breathing patterns. Furthermore, molecular studies have elucidated the role of the NTS in integrating sensory information from the lungs and other respiratory structures, thereby influencing breathing control. These findings have profound implications for our understanding of respiratory physiology and the development of novel therapeutic strategies for respiratory disorders. The integration of molecular biology and respiratory physiology has opened new avenues for research into the complex mechanisms governing breathing control.
